Annales des empereurs to japon, pp. 416-417. ==Events of the Kyōhō era== * 1717 (Kyōhō 2): Kyōhō reforms are directed and overseen by Shogun Yoshimune.Bowman, John Stewart. (2000). Columbia Chronologies of Asian History and Culture, p. 142. * 1718 (Kyōhō 3): The bakufu repaired the Imperial tombs.Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1956). Kyoto: the Old Capital, 794-1869, p. 320. * 1718 (Kyōhō 3, 8th month): Shogunate creates a in Heian- kyō (Kyoto). * 1721 (Kyōhō 6): Edo population of 1.1 million makes it the world's largest city.Foreign Press Center. (1997). Japan: Eyes on the Country, Views of the 47 Prefectures, p. 127. * 1730 (Kyōhō 15): The Tokugawa shogunate monitors the Dojima Rice Market in Osaka.Adams, Thomas. (1953). Japanese Securities Markets: A Historical Survey, pp. 11-12; Hayami, Akira et al. (2004) The Economic History of Japan: 1600-1990, p. 67. * 3 August 1730 (Kyōhō 15, 20th day of the 6th month): A fire destroyed 3,790 houses in Heian-kyō. * 1732 (Kyōhō 17): Locusts eat crops in areas around the inland sea.Hall, John Whitney. (1988). The Cambridge History of Japan, p. 456. * 24 September 1732 (Kyōhō 17, 24th day of the 9th month): Former-Emperor Reigen died.Meyer, Eva- Maria. (1999). Japans Kaiserhof in der Edo-Zeit, p. 186; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), 霊元天皇 (112); retrieved 2012-5-27. * 1733 (Kyōhō 18): Ginseng grown in Japan begins to be available in the Japanese food markets.Takekoshi, Yosaburō. (1930). Economic Aspects of the History of the Civilization of Japan, p. 352. * 13 April 1735 (Kyōhō 20, 21st day of the 3rd month) : Nakamikado abdicated; and the succession passed to his son (senso).Meyer, p. 47. Soon after, Empress Sakuamachi's role as monarch was confirmed by ceremonies (sokui).Titsingh, p. 417; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, p. 44; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fushimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Kunaichō, Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no-Rei); retrieved 2012-6-30. * 1735 (Kyōhō 20): Sweet potatoes were introduced into the Japanese diet.
